intro: Gagea commutata var. procera, commonly known as the tall gagea, is a perennial bulbous plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant produces clusters of white or pale pink flowers in early spring, which are typically bell-shaped and arranged in a loose inflorescence. It thrives in well-drained soils and prefers partial to full sun, often growing in open woodlands or rocky slopes. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
